text:
I love that during Pride Month
we get to celebrate
so many LGBTQ+ people

making a difference
in their communities.

Like our next guest,
Sameer Jha.
This GLAAD 20 Under 20 honoree
created their own organization,

the Empathy Alliance,
with a mission to make

all schools inclusive and
accepting for all students.

- This is me.
- Sameer, welcome.
So, Sameer, what inspired you

to want to make schools
safer for LGBTQ+ students?

Every single student
should be able to have
a safe place to learn.
I was bullied all throughout

elementary and middle school,
and it wasn't until high school

that I found an amazing
community of LGBTQ+ people.

I was really lucky
that I had all this support.

Even though I went through
a lot of terrible things,

I was able to turn that
into something good.

How did you get your start,
and what kinds of things
does your organization do?
When I was starting out at 14,

I didn't think anyone
would take a kid seriously.

But I went back to the middle
school where I had been bullied

and I talked to the counselor
and the principal

about everything
that I had faced there.
I ended up starting

the first ever GSA
at the school.

We got inclusive materials
in all the school libraries,

as well as made sure
the curriculum

was also inclusive
of all students.
How has your experience

helped make you
the leader you are today?

All of my different identities
have definitely

come together
to shape who I am.

In bridging my South Asian
community and LGBTQ+ community,

I think I've found a stronger
place in both of them.
Can I ask a quick question?

What does it mean
when people use they/them?

They/them pronouns work
just like every other pronoun.

Instead of calling someone
he or her, you can say "they."

Like, "They are my best friend."
Or, "I love them."

And I think the most important
thing is to ask someone

what they're comfortable
with you using.
What does Pride mean to you?

A celebration of all
the amazing LGBTQ+ people

that have accepted
who they are.

But it's also a time
to make sure everyone knows

that we still
need your support,

but together,
we can make a difference.

It has been amazing
speaking to you.

Thank you so much
for being here.

Thank you
so much for having me.
All: Happy Pride!
♪ This is me! ♪
